journal-title-group.journal-title: Journal of stroke and cerebrovascular diseases : the official journal of National Stroke Association

title-group.article-title: Influenza-Like Illness is Associated with Increased Short-Term Risk of Cervical Artery Dissection

article-meta.aff: *Vagelos College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, New York City, NY, USA;
†Department of Neurology, Vagelos College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, New York City, NY, USA;
‡Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics, Temple University College of Public Health, Philadelphia, PA, USA;
§Department of Epidemiology, Mailman School of Public Health, Columbia University, New York City, NY, USA.

fn.p: All authors were substantially involved in the revision of the manuscript and approved the final version. In addition, Dr. Mitchell Elkind was responsible for the study’s conception and design, supervision and obtaining funding, data interpretation, and critical revision of the manuscript. Dr. Amelia Boehme acquired the SPARCS data, analyzed the data, and was involved in the interpretation of results. Yeseon P Moon and Dr. Erin Kulick performed data analysis. Madeleine Hunter was involved in data interpretation and in drafting the manuscript. Dr. Eliza Miller acquired the validation study data. She then analyzed and interpreted the validation study’s results.
The authors have no conflicts of interest to declare.

sec.title: Introduction:
sec.p: Non-traumatic Cervical Artery Dissection (CeAD) is a leading cause of ischemic stroke in the young. Influenza-like illnesses (ILI) trigger ischemic strokes. We hypothesized that influenza and ILI are associated with CeAD.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: In a case-crossover study within the New York State (NYS) Department of Health State-wide Planning and Research Cooperative System (2006–2014), we used ICD-9 codes to exclude major trauma and to define CeAD, influenza, and the Centers for Disease Control defined ILI. We estimated the association of ILI and influenza with CeAD by comparing their prevalence in intervals immediately prior (0–30, 0–90,0–180, and 0–365 days) to CeAD (case period) to their prevalence exactly one and two years earlier (control periods). Conditional logistic regression models generated odds ratios and 95% confidence intervals (OR, 95% CI). Models were adjusted for NYS estimates of influenza prevalence rates.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Our sample included 3,610 cases of CeAD (mean age 52±16 years, 54.7% male, 6.2% Hispanic, 9.9% Black, 68.7% White). During case periods, 7.3% had one or more ILI. ILI was more likely within 90 days of CeAD compared to the same time interval one and two years before (0–15 days: adjusted OR 1.88, 95%CI 1.20–2.94; 0–30 days: adjusted OR 1.74, 95%CI 1.22–2.46; 0–90 days: adjusted OR 1.35, 95%CI 1.00–1.81). Influenza trended with CeAD (adjusted OR 1.86, 95%CI 0.37–9.24), but these results were not statistically significant, due to limited instances of confirmed influenza.

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: ILI may increase risk of CeAD for 15 days, and possibly up to three months.
